Capital is dead labor which, vampire-like, lives only by sucking living labor.
Religion is the opium of the people.
From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs.
religion: Atheism (born Jewish, family converted to Lutheranism)

works.title: The Eighteenth Brumaire of Louis Napoleon
works.description: Study of 1851 French coup. Famous opening: 'Hegel remarks that all great world-historic facts appear twice... first as tragedy, then as farce.'

books.title: Thus Spoke Zarathustra
books.description: Philosophical novel introducing the Übermensch (Overman) and eternal recurrence. Written in poetic prose.

books.title: Beyond Good and Evil
books.description: Critique of traditional morality. Distinguishes master-slave morality and announces the 'death of God'.

books.title: The Genealogy of Morals
books.description: Traces origins of moral concepts like guilt and punishment. Develops will to power theory.

books.title: The Birth of Tragedy
books.description: Early work contrasting Apollonian and Dionysian artistic forces. Includes critique of Socratic rationalism.

legacy: Misappropriated by Nazi ideology (against his philosophy)
name: Friedrich Nietzsche
notes: Mental collapse in 1889 (possibly from syphilis). Cared for by sister Elisabeth, who edited his works posthumously.
quotes: God is dead. God remains dead. And we have killed him.
He who has a why to live can bear almost any how.
That which does not kill us makes us stronger.
Whoever fights monsters should see to it that he does not become a monster.
You must have chaos within you to give birth to a dancing star.

works.title: Ecce Homo
works.description: Provocative self-assessment with chapters like 'Why I Am So Wise'. Written before mental collapse.

books.title: Science and Hypothesis
books.description: Foundational work on philosophy of science. Introduces conventionalism in geometry and physics.

books.title: The Value of Science
books.description: Explores epistemology of scientific knowledge. Discusses intuition vs. logic in mathematics.

books.title: The Foundations of Science
books.description: Compilation of major works. Includes 'Mathematical Creation' on subconscious problem-solving.

legacy: Last universalist in mathematics (worked across all fields)
Bridge between classical and modern physics
name: Henri Poincaré
notes: Cousin of French President Raymond Poincaré. Died suddenly from embolism at 58. Never won Nobel despite 51 nominations.
quotes: Science is built with facts, as a house is built with stones; but an accumulation of facts is no more science than a heap of stones is a house.
To doubt everything or to believe everything are two equally convenient solutions; both dispense with the need for thought.
The scientist does not study nature because it is useful; he studies it because he delights in it.

works.title: New Methods of Celestial Mechanics
works.description: Three-volume masterpiece on dynamical systems. Laid groundwork for chaos theory.

books.title: The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism
books.description: Seminal work linking Calvinist theology to modern capitalism's emergence. Introduces 'iron cage' of rationality.

books.title: Economy and Society
books.description: Posthumous magnum opus. Defines sociology, authority types (charismatic/rational/legal), and bureaucracy.

books.title: Politics as a Vocation
books.description: Lecture defining the state's monopoly on violence and ethics of conviction vs. responsibility.

name: Max Weber
notes: Nervous breakdown 1897-1902. Married Marianne Schnitger (feminist scholar). Died of Spanish flu complications.
quotes: The Protestant wanted to work in a calling; we are forced to do so.
Politics is the strong and slow boring of hard boards.
Specialists without spirit, sensualists without heart—this nullity imagines it has attained a level of civilization never before achieved.

works.title: The Sociology of Religion
works.description: Analyzes world religions' economic ethics. Unfinished project published posthumously.

books.title: Prison Notebooks (Quaderni del Carcere)
books.description: Written during imprisonment (1929-1935). Contains theories of cultural hegemony, organic intellectuals, and civil society. Published posthumously.

books.title: Selections from the Prison Notebooks
books.description: Curated compilation of key notebooks. Introduced Gramsci to Anglophone audiences.

concepts: War of position vs. war of maneuver
legacy: Key influence on critical theory and postcolonial studies
name: Antonio Gramsci
notes: Imprisoned by Mussolini's regime (1926). Wrote 33 notebooks in code to evade censors. Died days after release due to health deterioration.
quotes: The challenge of modernity is to live without illusions and without becoming disillusioned.
I'm a pessimist because of intelligence, but an optimist because of will.
Every social group has its own intellectuals who help maintain its hegemony.
The old world is dying, and the new world struggles to be born; now is the time of monsters.

works.title: Letters from Prison
works.description: Personal and theoretical letters to family and comrades. Reveals his 'pessimism of the intellect, optimism of the will.'

books.title: Principia Mathematica (with A.N. Whitehead)
books.description: Landmark 3-volume work attempting to derive mathematics from logic. Introduced theory of types to resolve paradoxes.

books.title: The Problems of Philosophy
books.description: Accessible introduction to epistemology. Distinguishes knowledge by acquaintance vs. description.

books.title: A History of Western Philosophy
books.description: Critically surveys philosophy from Thales to Dewey. Won Nobel Prize in Literature (1950).

books.title: Why I Am Not a Christian
books.description: Seminal critique of religious belief. Argues against first-cause and design arguments.

name: Bertrand Russell
notes: Imprisoned for pacifism in WWI. Lost Cambridge post due to anti-war views. Married 4 times. Campaigned against nuclear weapons.
quotes: The whole problem with the world is that fools and fanatics are always so certain of themselves, and wiser people so full of doubts.
War does not determine who is right - only who is left.
Three passions have governed my life: the longing for love, the search for knowledge, and unbearable pity for the suffering of mankind.

works.title: On Denoting
works.description: Seminal 1905 paper introducing definite descriptions theory. Called 'paradigm of philosophy' by Moore.

books.title: Being and Nothingness
books.description: Foundational text of existentialism. Introduces concepts of bad faith, radical freedom, and the 'gaze' of others.

books.title: Nausea
books.description: Existential novel depicting consciousness of freedom through protagonist Roquentin's crisis of meaning.

books.title: No Exit
books.description: Play famous for the line 'Hell is other people.' Explores interpersonal conflict and self-deception.

books.title: Critique of Dialectical Reason
books.description: Later Marxist-influenced work reconciling existential freedom with historical materialism.

name: Jean-Paul Sartre
notes: Lifelong partnership with Simone de Beauvoir (non-monogamous). Active in French Resistance. Supported Algerian independence. Blind in later years.
quotes: Man is condemned to be free; because once thrown into the world, he is responsible for everything he does.
Hell is other people.
Everything has been figured out, except how to live.
When the rich wage war, it's the poor who die.

works.title: Existentialism Is a Humanism
works.description: 1945 defense of existentialism against charges of nihilism. Argues for ethical responsibility in freedom.

books.title: Discipline and Punish: The Birth of the Prison
books.description: Analyzes the shift from sovereign power to disciplinary institutions. Introduces panopticon as metaphor for modern surveillance.

books.title: The History of Sexuality, Volume 1
books.description: Challenges 'repressive hypothesis,' arguing power produces sexuality. Introduces biopower and technologies of the self.

books.title: Madness and Civilization
books.description: Traces how madness became medicalized. Examines the Great Confinement and birth of psychiatry.

books.title: The Order of Things
books.description: Archaeology of human sciences. Famously predicts 'man would be erased, like a face drawn in sand.'

name: Michel Foucault
notes: Openly gay activist. Taught at Collège de France. Died of AIDS complications. Political activist (Prison Information Group).
quotes: Where there is power, there is resistance.
The soul is the prison of the body.
Knowledge is not for understanding; it is for cutting.
People know what they do; they frequently know why they do what they do; but what they don't know is what what they do does.

works.title: Society Must Be Defended
works.description: Collège de France lectures (1975-76) on race war discourse and biopolitics. Published posthumously.

books.title: The Great World-System
books.description: First known work proposing atomic theory. Claimed all matter composed of indivisible particles moving through void.

books.title: On Mind
books.description: Explained cognition through physical atomic interactions. Possibly influenced Democritus' psychology.

name: Leucippus
notes: Few fragments survive. Often conflated with Democritus. Aristotle credits him with originating atomism despite later obscurity.
quotes: Nothing happens at random; everything happens out of reason and necessity.
The universe is boundless, with infinite atoms moving eternally in infinite void.
Reality is atoms and void; all else is opinion.

works.title: Fragments (reconstructed)
works.description: Quotations preserved by Aristotle, Theophrastus, and Simplicius. Discuss vortex formation of cosmic systems.

books.title: On the Infinite Universe and Worlds
books.description: Radical cosmological work rejecting geocentrism. Argues for infinite universe with innumerable inhabited worlds.

books.title: The Ash Wednesday Supper
books.description: Defends Copernican heliocentrism while proposing even more radical cosmic plurality beyond it.

books.title: On the Heroic Frenzies
books.description: Neoplatonic treatise linking cosmic infinity to human intellectual and spiritual ascent.

name: Giordano Bruno
notes: Dominican friar who fled order in 1576. Wandered Europe teaching controversial ideas. Imprisoned by Inquisition for 7 years before execution.
quotes: The universe is then one, infinite, immobile... It is not capable of comprehension and therefore is endless and limitless.
Perhaps your fear in passing judgment on me is greater than mine in receiving it.
There is no absolute up or down, as Aristotle taught; no absolute position in space.

works.title: On the Composition of Images
works.description: Complex memory system using astrological symbols and magic. Part of his occult teachings.

books.title: Letters to Bernard of Arezzo
books.description: Challenges Aristotelian epistemology. Argues all non-tautological knowledge is merely probable, not certain.

books.title: Exigit ordo executionis
books.description: Condemned treatise proposing radical skepticism. Only survives in quotations from condemnation documents.

name: Nicolaus of Autrecourt
notes: Forced to burn his writings publicly in 1347. Later became dean of Metz Cathedral. Surviving works reconstructed from condemnation records.
quotes: From the fact that one thing is known to exist, it cannot be inferred that another exists.
We can be certain only of what is immediately apparent to us.
All non-logical knowledge is at best probable.

works.title: Fragments on Certainty
works.description: Reconstructed arguments against scholastic certainty. Claims even causal relations are unprovable.

books.title: On Learned Ignorance
books.description: Proposes 'docta ignorantia' - that true wisdom lies in recognizing the limits of human knowledge, especially regarding God.

books.title: The Vision of God
books.description: Mystical treatise using an icon as meditation tool to understand God as the 'coincidence of opposites'.

books.title: On the Peace of Faith
books.description: Early interfaith dialogue proposing harmony among religions under one universal faith, written after the fall of Constantinople.

legacy: Bridge between medieval and Renaissance thought
name: Nicholas of Cusa
notes: Cardinal and polymath. Proposed calendar reform. Built the St. Nicholas Hospital (still exists) with Europe's first medical reference library.
quotes: The intellect is to truth as the polygon is to the circle... the more sides it has, the more it resembles the circle.
God is an infinite sphere whose center is everywhere and circumference nowhere.
There is no proportion between the finite and the infinite.

works.title: On the Quadrature of the Circle
works.description: Early attempt to solve the classic problem, demonstrating his interdisciplinary approach.

books.title: Syntagma Philosophicum
books.description: Posthumous magnum opus systematizing his Epicurean atomism, empirical epistemology, and reconciliation with Christianity.

books.title: Disquisitio Metaphysica
books.description: Detailed critique of Descartes' Meditations, defending empirical skepticism and probabilistic knowledge.

books.title: De Vita et Moribus Epicuri
books.description: Rehabilitation of Epicurus' philosophy, separating his atomism from accusations of hedonism.

legacy: Reviver of atomism in early modern science
name: Pierre Gassendi
notes: Priest who held ecclesiastical positions while advancing radical philosophy. Observed 1631 Mercury transit. Debated Descartes and Hobbes.
quotes: There is nothing in the intellect that has not first been in the senses - not even the intellect itself.
Nature acts by means of fewest and smallest possible instruments: atoms and void.
To know is to measure what can be measured and to render measurable what cannot be measured.

works.title: Observations on the Transit of Mercury
works.description: 1631 astronomical records supporting Keplerian elliptical orbits. Used camera obscura for precision.

books.title: On Truth (also called The Throws)
books.description: Contained his famous 'man-measure' doctrine. Began: 'Man is the measure of all things...'

books.title: On the Gods
books.description: Opening line questioning divine knowledge led to his Athenian exile for impiety.

name: Protagoras
notes: First thinker to charge tuition fees. Allegedly drowned after being expelled from Athens for agnosticism. Taught Pericles' sons.
quotes: Man is the measure of all things: of the things that are, that they are; of the things that are not, that they are not.
Concerning the gods, I cannot know whether they exist or not, nor what form they might have.
There are two opposing arguments about everything.

works.title: Art of Controversy
works.description: Techniques for making weaker arguments defeat stronger ones. Inspired later rhetorical handbooks.

books.title: On Nature or the Non-Existent
books.description: Radical skeptical treatise with three theses: (1) Nothing exists; (2) If anything exists, it cannot be known; (3) If knowable, it cannot be communicated.

books.title: Encomium of Helen
books.description: Rhetorical showpiece defending Helen of Troy, demonstrating the power of persuasion to alter perceived reality.

books.title: Defense of Palamedes
books.description: Forensic speech exemplifying how to construct arguments from probability (eikos) in absence of evidence.

legacy: Model for Plato's critique of sophistry
name: Gorgias
notes: Lived over 100 years. Ambassador to Athens in 427 BCE where his speeches caused a sensation. Never charged fixed fees but accepted gifts. Statue erected at Delphi.
quotes: Speech is a powerful lord that with the smallest and most invisible body accomplishes most divine works.
Nothing exists; if anything exists, it cannot be known; if knowable, it cannot be communicated.
Being is unrecognizable unless it becomes opinion.

works.title: Funeral Oration
works.description: Lost work mentioned by ancient sources as exemplary display of ceremonial speaking.

books.title: Synagoge (Collection)
books.description: Encyclopedic work spanning astronomy, mathematics, history, and literature. First known attempt to systematize diverse knowledge.

books.title: Olympic Discourse
books.description: Speech delivered at Olympia advocating Panhellenic unity. Showcased his mnemonic techniques by reciting 50 names after one hearing.

legacy: Model of the Renaissance man before the Renaissance
Influenced Plato's critique of superficial knowledge
Early contributor to quadratrix curve in geometry
name: Hippias of Elis
notes: Boasted he could speak extemporaneously on any topic. Wore only self-made clothes and jewelry. Appears as a character in Plato's dialogues.
quotes: I have never met any man who was my superior in anything.
Law, tyrant of mankind, often compels us to do many things contrary to nature.
All these arts I have mastered so that no man may surpass me.

works.title: List of Olympic Victors
works.description: First systematic chronology of Greek history using Olympic victor lists as temporal framework.

books.title: On Nature
books.description: Materialist work positing that early humans deified useful natural phenomena (sun, moon, rivers) as gods.

books.title: The Hours (Horai)
books.description: Allegorical choice between Virtue and Vice, influencing Heracles' choice in Xenophon's Memorabilia.

name: Prodicus
notes: Charged up to 50 drachmas per lecture. Plato parodied his 'voice like a bee's hum.' Often sent as Ceos' ambassador to Athens.
quotes: The correct use of words is the beginning of wisdom.
Men have made gods in their own image, deeming useful things divine.
Virtue speaks plainly, while Vice whispers sweetly.

works.title: On the Correctness of Names
works.description: Systematic distinctions between near-synonyms (e.g., courage vs. recklessness). Influenced Plato's Cratylus.

books.title: On Truth
books.description: Radical materialist work distinguishing natural law (physis) from human convention (nomos). Argues all men are equal by nature.

books.title: Tetralogies
books.description: Three sets of four model forensic speeches (accusation/defense/rebuttals) showing probabilistic argumentation techniques.

name: Antiphon
notes: Leader of the 411 BCE oligarchic coup. Wrote speeches for others while avoiding public appearances. Executed after democratic restoration.
quotes: Justice is not violating the rules of the city in which one lives as a citizen.
By nature we are all equal in every way, barbarians and Greeks alike.
Time is a thought or a measure, not a substance.

works.title: On Concord
works.description: Lost work advocating social harmony through enlightened self-interest. Criticized excessive ambition.

books.title: Constitutions
books.description: Comparative study of political systems, including Sparta's constitution which he idealized. Survives in quotes by Aristotle.

books.title: Sisyphus Fragment
books.description: Atheistic drama fragment arguing gods were invented to deter secret crimes. Attributed to Critias or Euripides.

legacy: Model for Plato's Republic's dystopian elements
name: Critias
notes: Plato's uncle. Banished under democracy, returned to lead pro-Spartan oligarchy (404 BCE). Killed fighting democratic restoration forces.
quotes: There was a time when human life was unordered... then laws restrained the hands of men.
A clever man invented fear of the gods for mortals, that there might be some means of frightening the wicked.
The strongest rules are always the best rules.

works.title: Elegies
works.description: Extolled Spartan discipline. One fragment praises drinking parties as revealing true character.

concepts: Justice as the advantage of the stronger
name: Thrasymachus
notes: Sophist known primarily through Plato's Republic. His actual views may differ from Plato's portrayal.
quotes: Justice is nothing else than the interest of the stronger.
Each government frames the laws to suit its own advantage.
The just is always a loser in comparison with the unjust.

works.title: None extant
works.description: Known to have written rhetorical treatises, all lost

birth_place: Roman Africa (likely modern Tunisia or Algeria)

books.title: Commentaries on Cicero's Rhetorical Works
books.description: Early works on rhetoric, influenced by Neoplatonism

books.title: Against Arius
books.description: Theological treatises defending Nicene Christianity

legacy: Bridge between pagan philosophy and Christian theology
name: Marius Victorinus
notes: Converted from paganism to Christianity in old age. His works were preserved by Augustine who admired him.
quotes: God is being itself; creatures participate in being.
The Son is the Father's self-knowledge.
Rhetoric without wisdom is empty; wisdom without rhetoric is mute.

works.title: Translation of Porphyry's Isagoge
works.description: Key text for medieval Aristotelian logic

works.title: Hymns on the Trinity
works.description: Early example of Latin Christian hymns

books.title: The Consolation of Philosophy
books.description: Dialogue between Boethius and Lady Philosophy on fate, free will, and divine providence

books.title: De Institutione Musica
books.description: Foundational text on music theory, linking mathematics to harmony

legacy: Bridge between classical and medieval thought
name: Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius
notes: Served as consul under Theodoric the Great. Imprisoned and executed for alleged treason. Wrote 'Consolation' in prison.
quotes: Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.
Music is part of us, and either ennobles or degrades our behavior.
Nothing is miserable unless you think it so.
teachers: Quintus Aurelius Memmius Symmachus (father-in-law and mentor)

works.title: Opuscula Sacra
works.description: Five treatises on Christian doctrine and Trinity

works.title: Translations of Aristotle
works.description: Translated Aristotle's logical works into Latin (Categories, On Interpretation)

books.title: Etymologiae (Origines)
books.description: First encyclopedia of the Middle Ages, 20-volume compilation of classical knowledge

books.title: De Ecclesiasticis Officiis
books.description: Liturgical manual explaining Christian rites and ceremonies

legacy: Last scholar of the ancient world
name: Isidore of Seville
notes: Presided over 4th Council of Toledo (633). Brother of St. Leander and St. Fulgentius. Died surrounded by monks washing the poor.
quotes: Letters are signs of things, symbols of words.
War with vices, peace with virtues.
If a man wants to be always in God's company, he must pray regularly and read regularly.

works.title: Historia de regibus Gothorum
works.description: Chronicle of Visigothic kings promoting Hispanic unity

works.title: De Natura Rerum
works.description: Cosmological treatise blending Scripture and classical science

books.title: Periphyseon (De Divisione Naturae)
books.description: Neoplatonic synthesis dividing nature into four categories, blending Christian theology with Greek philosophy

books.title: Homily on the Prologue to John's Gospel
books.description: Mystical interpretation of the Logos, influenced by Greek patristics

death_place: Possibly West Francia (modern France) or England
legacy: Greatest philosopher of the Carolingian era
Pioneer of Christian Neoplatonism in the West
Influenced later mystics like Meister Eckhart
Works condemned in 1210 for pantheistic tendencies
name: John Scotus Eriugena
notes: Called to Charles the Bald's court as a Greek scholar. Legend claims he was stabbed to death by students' pens.
quotes: Authority comes from reason, not reason from authority.
God does not know what He is because He is not a what.
All things that are, are lights.
students: Possible influence on Remigius of Auxerre

works.title: Translation of Pseudo-Dionysius
works.description: First complete Latin version of Dionysian corpus, foundational for medieval mysticism

works.title: De Praedestinatione
works.description: Controversial work on free will and predestination, condemned at synods

books.title: First Apology
books.description: Defense of Christianity addressed to Emperor Antoninus Pius, explaining Christian practices and beliefs

books.title: Dialogue with Trypho
books.description: Debate with a Jewish scholar demonstrating how Christ fulfills Old Testament prophecies

legacy: Pioneer of Christological interpretation of Hebrew scriptures
name: Justin Martyr
notes: Converted after encountering an old man who pointed him to Hebrew prophets. Martyred with six companions under Junius Rusticus.
quotes: The seed of Reason (Logos) was implanted in every race of men.
No one believes anything unless they first thought it believable.
We pray for our persecutors.

works.title: Second Apology
works.description: Supplement addressing Roman persecution and pagan accusations

works.title: On the Resurrection
works.description: Fragments survive, defending bodily resurrection

books.title: Protrepticus (Exhortation to the Greeks)
books.description: Rhetorical appeal to abandon paganism, comparing Greek myths to Christian truth

books.title: Paedagogus (The Tutor)
books.description: Practical guide to Christian living, covering ethics, etiquette, and daily conduct

concepts: Philosophy as God's preparation for Greeks
legacy: Bridge between Greek philosophy and Christianity
name: Titus Flavius Clemens (Clement of Alexandria)
notes: Succeeded Pantaenus as head of Alexandrian Catechetical School. Fled Alexandria during persecution in 202 CE.
quotes: Just as the will of God is creation, so his intention is the salvation of what he created.
The Logos of God became man so that you might learn from man how man may become God.
All wisdom is one, just as all truth is one.
teachers: Various Greek philosophers (per his own account)

works.title: Stromata (Miscellanies)
works.description: Seven-volume collection exploring faith through philosophy, scripture, and gnosis

works.title: Who is the Rich Man That Shall Be Saved?
works.description: Exegesis of Mark 10:17-31, advocating spiritual detachment over literal poverty

books.title: De Principiis (On First Principles)
books.description: First systematic Christian theology, exploring cosmology, free will, and Scripture's multiple senses

books.title: Contra Celsum (Against Celsus)
books.description: Apologetic masterpiece refuting pagan philosopher Celsus' anti-Christian arguments

concepts: The eternal generation of the Son
legacy: Most prolific early Christian writer (6,000 works claimed)
Influenced Cappadocian Fathers and monastic theology
Posthumously condemned (553 CE) for disputed teachings
name: Origen Adamantius
notes: Castrated himself literally/metaphorically (disputed). Tortured in Decian persecution. Died from injuries.
quotes: The end of the world is the end of sin.
Scripture is like a many-layered onion.
Prayer is conversation with God.

works.title: Hexapla
works.description: Six-column Old Testament comparing Hebrew, Greek versions (mostly lost)

works.title: Commentary on John
works.description: Longest extant commentary (32 vols), exploring Christ as Logos

books.title: Against Heresies (Adversus Haereses)
books.description: Five-volume refutation of Gnosticism, preserving early Christian theology and Gnostic texts

books.title: Demonstration of the Apostolic Preaching
books.description: Catechetical summary of Christian faith linking Old Testament prophecies to Christ

concepts: Unity of Old and New Testaments
legacy: First systematic theologian of the Church
Bridge between Eastern and Western theology
name: Irenaeus of Lyon
notes: Survived the 177 CE Lyon persecution. Possibly martyred under Septimius Severus. Feast day: June 28.
quotes: The glory of God is man fully alive.
Error, indeed, is never set forth in its naked deformity.
The Church is the entrance to life.
teachers: Polycarp of Smyrna (direct disciple of John the Apostle)

works.title: Fragments of Lost Letters
works.description: On Easter controversy and papal authority (preserved in Eusebius)

works.title: Sermons
works.description: Lost works mentioned by Jerome

books.title: Sic et Non (Yes and No)
books.description: Dialectical method presenting 158 theological questions with contradictory patristic quotations

books.title: Historia Calamitatum (Story of My Misfortunes)
books.description: Autobiographical letter detailing his love affair with Héloïse and career struggles

legacy: Founder of Paris University intellectual tradition
Influenced Peter Lombard and later scholastics
name: Peter Abelard (Pierre Abélard)
notes: Castrated by Héloïse's uncle Fulbert. Buried with Héloïse at Père Lachaise Cemetery (Paris).
quotes: By doubting we come to inquiry; by inquiring we perceive the truth.
The key to wisdom is constant and frequent questioning.
Love is not a fire which can be confined.

works.title: Theologia 'Summi Boni'
works.description: Condemned at Soissons (1121) for rationalist approach to Trinity

works.title: Ethics (Scito Te Ipsum)
works.description: Groundbreaking work on intentionality and sin

works.title: Love Letters to Héloïse
works.description: Celebrated medieval correspondence (authenticity debated)

books.title: Summa Theologica (Doctoris Irrefragabilis)
books.description: First systematic theology incorporating Aristotelian philosophy and Franciscan spirituality

books.title: Glossa in Quatuor Libros Sententiarum
books.description: Commentary on Peter Lombard's Sentences, foundational for scholastic method

name: Alexander of Hales (Alexander Halensis)
notes: Joined Franciscans in 1236 while already a famous professor. His Summa was completed by students posthumously.
quotes: Grace does not destroy nature but perfects it.
Theology begins where philosophy ends.
Love is the weight of the soul.

works.title: Quaestiones Disputatae
works.description: 78 disputed questions on Trinity, Christology, and sacraments

works.title: Expositio Regulae Franciscanae
works.description: Theological defense of Franciscan Rule

books.title: De Mineralibus (On Minerals)
books.description: Pioneering work on geology and mineralogy blending Aristotelian philosophy with empirical observation

books.title: Summa Theologiae
books.description: Systematic theology incorporating Aristotelian metaphysics and natural science

legacy: Bridge between Islamic and Christian science
name: Albertus Magnus (Saint Albert the Great)
notes: Canonized in 1931. First scholar to comment on all works of Aristotle. Legend claims he created an android.
quotes: The aim of natural science is not simply to accept the statements of others, but to investigate the causes that are at work in nature.
There is no such thing as a small science.
Experiment is the only safe guide in science.

works.title: De Animalibus (On Animals)
works.description: 26-volume zoological encyclopedia based on Aristotle and original observations

works.title: Commentaries on Aristotle
works.description: Complete exegesis of Aristotelian corpus (physics, metaphysics, ethics)

books.title: Ordinatio (Opus Oxoniense)
books.description: Magnum opus systematizing theology at Oxford, introducing haecceity and univocity of being

books.title: Reportatio Parisiensis
books.description: Lecture notes from Paris period on metaphysics and divine infinity

legacy: Influenced Peirce, Heidegger, and analytic philosophy
name: John Duns Scotus
notes: Buried in Cologne's Minoritenkirche. Left works unfinished due to early death. Feast day: November 8.
quotes: God is a being concerning whom no greater can be conceived.
Will is the rational power of self-determination.
Theology is practical knowledge ordered to love.

works.title: Quaestiones Quodlibetales
works.description: Disputed questions on free will, divine knowledge, and ethics

works.title: De Primo Principio
works.description: Metaphysical proof of God's existence through causality

books.title: The Soul's Journey into God (Itinerarium Mentis in Deum)
books.description: Mystical treatise outlining six stages of spiritual ascent through creation to divine contemplation

books.title: Breviloquium
books.description: Concise summary of Christian theology from a Franciscan perspective

legacy: Patron saint of bowel disorders (from childhood miracle)
name: Giovanni di Fidanza (Saint Bonaventure)
notes: Healed as child by Francis of Assisi (according to tradition). Died while participating in Council of Lyon.
quotes: The perfection of a Christian is to do common things in a perfect way.
In everything, whether it is a thing sensed or a thing known, God himself is hidden within.
